tagDescription: R.B. Forbes: Refers to order for engine and boiler for ship for China trade.
John A. Stevens: Replies to cautionary advice.
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring: Discusses the issuing the currency bonds and other financial matters.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring: With regard to the Government changing their account.
J.T. White to J. Bates: Enclosing memo of his interview with Mr. Bushby in relation to the Santa Cruz estate.
J.C. Burnham & Co.: Exports of sugar.
J.C. Burnham & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Refers to the probable settlement of the Trent affair - Comments on the prospects of the sugar crop.
Lawrence Son & Pearey to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. Debentures of the Eastern Railroad of Massachusetts.
John A. Stevens to Baring Bros. & Co. The money market at home and abroad.
R.B. Forbes to Capt. Dumaresq - Re his speculation in wax. (Press Copy)

J.M. Forbes & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Urging, at great length, that a stand should promptly be taken by the British in regard to the present depredations by sea if their interests are to be promoted and the peace of the world secured.
United States Sessional Paper: Resolution in respect to the Treaty of 1817 regulating the naval forces on the Great Lakes.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring: Answering enquiries re. Mr. Fox.
G. Kemble to T. Baring, M.P.: The policy of the new President - Johnson.
George Basil Dixwell to J. Bates - Affairs in China - commercial and political - Asks his opinion on the effect peace would have on the commerce and finances of the United States.
Edward Cardwell, Secretary for the Colonies: Advises that communications should go through the governor.
W. Beech: Refers to drawing bills of Exchange.
Wm. B. Hartley to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. business in connection with Colt's Patent Fire Arms Manufacturing Co.
W.L.: Comments on Lincoln's antislavery triumph, and fears that speculation in stocks will hurt English capitalists.
R. Baring Gould to T. Baring, M.P.: Asking information re. the allowance made to Mrs. Charles Baring during the lifetime of the late Lord Northbrook.
W.H. Aspinwall to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. Government Loan - Recruiting the Army - Rumours of a Loan Combined with a system of emigration &c.
Horace Binney to Thomson Hankey - On the disturbed state of the country, politically and financially.
Thomas Aspinwall to Baring Bros. & Co.: Forwarding remittances - Attitude of the Southern States towards the Union.

C.H. Russell, President, National Bank of Commerce, New York, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Enquires whether a Loan of one to five million dollars of United States six per cent bonds can be effected readily in London.
S.A. Way to Mr. Sturgis: With regard to opening an account with Hottinguer & Co. Paris.
E.H. Green to Sturgis: Thanks for action on Madrid bills. Sugar & hemp purchases.
T.G. Cary Jr. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Enclosing letter concerning the financial standing of Messrs. Hurtado & Bros.
W.H. Aspinwall to T . Baring: Enclosing note from Mr. Chase.
E.H. Derby to R. Sturgis: Re. a contribution on the Finances and Revenue of the United States which he wishes to have published in The Edinburg Review.

T.R. Waring, Cashier Bank South Carolina, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Asking an expression of their views as to the policy which will govern England in the event of a separation of South Carolina form the Union - Details the advantages of such a separation.
R.T. Dana to Sturgis - Re Mr. Lodge's application for a credit to Russell & Co. for account of himself & D.D. & Co. for Â£30,000.
John A. Stevens, Bank of Commerce: Demand for money for war expenditures; change in fiscal policy.
Charles W. Eliot to Russell Sturgis: Reservations for sailing aboard the ship Europe.
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring: Requesting information re. credit of the Chilian Government.
J.M. Forbes to Joshua Bates - Michigan Central affairs.
John A. Stevens to J. Bates - Complaining of the high commission upon transactions which pass into their general account - Gives much confidential information re their business transactions &c.
J.M. Forbes & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. the extension of a conditional guarantee to the Lansing Railroad Bonds by the Michigan Central Co.
John B. Camden to Baring Bros. & Co.: Proposal re. Bonds of the State of Mississippi given to the Union Bank.
Chas. Baring to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. establishing Richard B. Gould in some position in the United States.
C. Barns to Baring Bros. & Co.: Prophesies that the Civil War will be ended in sixty days and advises large investments in American Stocks.
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring: Pays tribute to Mr. Bates - The State of the country politically and financially.
T.C. Baring to T. Baring: Personal matters with regard to his projected return to England.
T.C. Baring to T. Baring, M.P.: Notifies him of the death of Lincoln, and discusses possible consequences.
G. Panis (?): Political views Conflict between Prussia & Austria. Fenian raids.
Geo. G. Glyn: Refers to money draft of Ward.
A. Guillemin to Baring Bros. & Co.: Introducing his brother-in-law M. Jules de Larbre, Minister of Marine, France.
Charles Baring to T. Baring - Requesting him to get a commission in the Navy for young Alexander Baring.
W.H. Aspinwall to Baring Bros. & Co.: Prospects of greatly increased gold yield - enclosing letter from Samuel A.M. Barlow, Explaining the new process of chemical treatment of the pulverised ores &c.
R.W. Weston to T. Baring, M.P.: Relative to his declining to be one of the Trustees of Mr. Bates' will under the Â£5000 Trust to Mrs. Cowing and her daughters.
The Hannibal and St. Joseph Railroad - History of the Road and its present condition.
T.C. Baring to T. Baring, M.P. Re. panic in Stocks and Exchange - excitement in Southern States, especially South Carolina.
Blake Bros. & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. Massachusetts bonds.
J.T. White to R. Sturgis: Refers to Mr. McDonald.
J.B. Gossler, Hamburg, to Baring Bros. & Co.: In reply to enquiry re United States Bonds being in demand by emigrants to be used in payment of Government Lands.
R.H. Maury & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Cotton a good investment - Advance in State Bonds &c.
G.H. Karg to Baring Bros. & Co.: His account with them - Political and financial state of Chili.
T.C. Baring to T. Baring, M.P.: Concerning his new position with Baring Bros. & Co.
T.C. Baring to T. Baring - Affairs of the firm of Ward, Campbell and Co.

John A. Stevens ,President Bank of Commerce, New York, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Notifying them that he has been authorized to accept the basis on which the future account between their firm and the Bank is proposed to be placed.
Wm. Ropes: Drafts against cotton purchases for shipment to St. Petersburg.
George Baty Blake to T. Baring, M.P.: Introducing his son, Mr. Stanton Blake, who is prepared to lay before him the financial condition and money wants of the State of Massachusetts.
E.B. Graves to Baring Bros. & Co.: Asking for information re. terms upon which they might do business with them.
George G. Hobson to Baring Bros. & Co.: Enquires if they would accept a consignment of Bolivia Guano and upon what terms.
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring, M.P.: The "Meteor" and the trial - McCulloch and the finances.
Eugene Rousseau to Baring Bros. & Co.: Concerning the account of the Citizens' Bank of New Orleans.
George P.Beschor, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Enclosing Prospectus of Nicaragua - a Cotton State with Free Labour.
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring: Legislation re. Cotton seizures - Political and military news &c.
J.M. Forbes & Co. to W.H. Aspinwall: Re. establishment of a large National Bank - Enclosed in 20/4/1864.
Grant & Son to ________ Contradicting the report that Wm.B. Reed had been arrested as a seceder by the Government.
N.M. Beckwith to T. Baring, M.P.: Enclosing an article from the "Tribune" touching on several points in regard to the Rebellion - Comments also on Mexican affairs.
T.C. Baring to T. Baring: Politics - Matters pertaining to their private account &c.
J.M. Forbes: Establishment of a National Bank, Encloses letter from S.G. Ward of 19/4/1864 with authority to draw on Barings for Â£100,000.
The Cotton market.
Teas - Facts with regard to Teas to America.
T.C. Baring to T. Baring, M.P.: Concerning his offer of a position in their office.
Frank L. Newton to J. Bates: Explanation of Bills drawn by him and negotiated through the Colonial Bank, being dishonoured.
List of banking firms with the names of their clients holding bonds - 5% & 6%. Also a general list of English firms.
J.B. Sharp to T. Baring, M.P. Re. formation of a Public Company owning large landed property in the State of Georgia - with considerable quantities to timber.
Lee, Higginson & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Concerning their business relations.

Robert Cecil to T. Baring , M.P.: In the matter of his having charged the House of Baring with having exported munitions of war to the Federal States, in violation of H.M. Proclamation of Neutrality. N.B. Enclosed is a press copy of Mr. Baring's letter to which the above is an answer.
Wm.L. Winans to Baring Bros. & Co.: Asking information re. terms of the rearrangement of a portion of the United States Loan.
Wm.L. Winans to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. United Stocks he is willing to buy.
G.C. Ward to J. Bates - An account of his connection with Mr. Florence Huertas.
Bill to provide a national currency secured by a pledge of United States Bonds and to provide for the circulation and redemption thereof.
T.C. Baring to T. Baring: Financial conditions of the State of Virginia.
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring, M.P.: Re. relations with France &c.
Theo. S. Fay, United States Legation, to J. Bates - Relative to the draft for his salary - The Civil War.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring: Financial matters - The permanent agency of the Government - Refers to letter from Mr. Withers relative to a commercial establishment at New Orleans.
Blake Bros. & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Sale of Massachusetts Bonds.
R.H. Maury & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Advising them to invest in Cotton, giving reasons for his expectations of profit, filed with 19/12/1862.
H.T. Machin to Baring Bros. & Co.: Has established himself at Portland, Maine as a Commission Merchant and asks for their business.
B.F. Gallaher to Baring Bros. & Co.: Proposals to form a Company of English capitalists to work a zinc mine discovered in one of the Southern States.
James Stewart to Baring Bros. & Co.: Concerning his operations in Cotton.
W.H. Swift to Thos. Baring - On the question of the relative cost of transportation by railway or by water carriage.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring: His opinion of Hon. G.V. Fox - Financial crisis following the return of peace - Failure of Overend, Gurney & Co.
Securities for the debts of Grant, More & Co. and Grant Balfour & Co.
R.B. Forbes to J. Bates, On the subject of orders on the house by Russell & Co. &c. Has finished the superintending of the construction of the 23 gunboats for the Government.
Joshua Bates: Refers to the Venezuela loan.
John A. Stevens to Baring Bros. & Co.: Instructions re importation of arms and munitions of war from Great Britain and France.
C. Goethe Baylor to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. "European and Southern Direct Trading Company" and their desire to negotiate the unpaid Bonds of Florida, Mississippi and Arkansas.
Aug. Heard: Refers to Russian credits.
J.M. Forbes. Cotton legislation. Political & war news.
J. Watson Webb, American Minister to Brazil, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Regarding this drafts - Describes troubles stirred up by the British Minister.

Harrison Ritchie, Lt. Col. and A.D.C., to Baring Bros. & Co.: Asking for funds to be applied to the purchase of guns on behalf of the State of Massachusetts - after a detailed statement of this position with necessary documents enclosed.
Russell Sturgis to W.G. Hodgkinson: Investment in the Philadelphia & Erie Railroad. Also letter from W.G. Hodgkinson of 28/2/1866.
J.T. White: Santa Cruz estate. Encloses letter from Thomas Bushby.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring, M.P.: Discusses resumption of Specie payment - Introduces Mr. Livermore.
Wm. H. Aspinwall: Refers to the 5/20s Bonds of the United States.
Hiram Roberts, President of Merchants and Planters Bank, Savannah, to Baring Bros. & Co. Liverpool - Re. desire to transact business through them.
Hiram Roberts to Baring Bros. & Co.: Liverpool - Re. Bills of Exchange to be received by them from the Bank of Commerce, New York.
John A. Stevens, Bank of Commerce: Refers to loan covered by United States securities.
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring: Re. sale of the issues of the five - twenties - His views on the probable outcome of the war.
W.H. Swift to S.G. Ward - Illinois and Michigan Canal-Claim of Claim Leavitt.
J.C. Burnham & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: The Sugar Market.
R.B. Forbes to T. Baring , M.P.: In relation to a projected tour of inspection of the life saving means in use in foreign countries.
John A. Stevens, President Bank of Commerce, New York to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. money and political affairs.
Blake Bros. & Co.: Massachusetts Bonds.
J.M. Forbes to J. Bates - Comments on the Bank Bill.
Arch. Gracie: Personal; leaves for Boston.
Joshua Bates to-Young - Re. Grand Trunk and other shares - Grand Trunk celebration of the Atlantic Telegraph.
W.A. Buffum to Baring Bros. & Co;: Re. probable gold production at Pike's Peak &c.

C.H. Fisher to Baring Bros. & Co.: Enclosing a newspaper Extract by Joseph Harrison Jr. to correct statements in some English papers about the fraud of American management of Russian Railways - and asking for its publication.
R.H. Maury & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Description of the Battle of Bull Run.
W.H. Swift to Baring Bros. & Co. & Messrs. Matheson & Co.: Illinois and Michigan Canal - Proceedings of the annual meeting of the Board of Trustees.
"Smith" to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. swindling in connection with the Detroit and Niagara Rivers Railroad.
C. Balfour to T. Baring, M.P.: Re. drawing against his account at Leghorn.
John A. Stevens to Baring Bros. & Co.: Business arrangements between the Bank of Commerce, New York, and their House.

George A. Halsted, Secretary Lloyd's, to T. Baring M.P., Chairman Lloyd's. Transmitting a letter signed by upwards of a hundred members of Lloyd's on the subject of the captures of British and neutral vessels on neutral voyages, by Federal cruisers.
John A. Stevens, Bank of Commerce: Advises of $500,000 shipment of gold, which completes the order for $2,500,000.
Stanton Blake: (2 letters) Massachusetts loan.
John A. Stevens, Bank of Commerce in New York: Effect of tight money market on shipments of British goods.
Wm. H. Webb to Baring Bros. & Co.: Requesting them to furnish the guarantee required by the Spanish Government in order that he may construct a frigate for that Government.
Wm. Appleton to Joshua Bates - Asking information as to ways and means of raising revenue to pay interest on their public debt.
Stanton Blake: Massachusetts Sterling Bonds.
G.C. Ward to T. Baring: Re. Lord Ashburton's Will.
G.C. Ward to T. Baring - Debit Balances - The safety of the American in the hands of S.G. Ward.
Christian Wald: Asks for a loan of Â£300,000 to settle Norwegian immigrants.
Col. George L. Schuyler to Baring Bros. & Co.: Relative to contracts made in Paris for his Government and requesting them to establish a credit for them.
C.H. Marshall to Baring Bros. & Co.: In reference to the depredations committed upon commerce by the Rebel Steamer Alabama.
C.H. Fisher to T. Baring, M.P. : Re. Loan for the Camden and Amboy Railroad and Delaware and Raritan Canal Co.
T.C. Baring (W.C. & Co.) to T. Baring, Regarding their over-drawn account - Political and military news - The case of the "Florida".

John A. Stevens to Baring Bros. & Co.: Men of eminent commercial standing in Great Britain said to be in favour of forcing their supplies of cotton from United States without delay, which would undoubtedly lead to an immediate and obstinate war.
Circular - The Pittsburgh, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railway Company. N.B. Certain Ms explanatory notes on the last page.
Joshua Bates to T. Baring - Grand Trunk matters - The partnership of Ward, Campbell and Co. James Odier's affairs.
W.H. Aspinwall to Baring Bros. & Co.: The progress of the war being delayed by political affairs. Discusses monetary affairs at some length.
G.C. Schutz to Baring Bros. & Co.: Relative to a Bill of Exchange drawn by the firm of Perret Schutz & Co. at New Orleans - (Draft letter).

Wm. Rathbone Jr. to -------. Enclosing heads of the argument likely to produce effect if addressed confidentially by Mr. Baring to Lord Russell, on the relations between England and the United States.
Lord Robert Cecil to T. Baring, M.P.: His opinion of the construction that should be placed on the language of the Queen's Proclamation of neutrality.
Blake Bros. & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: On the subject of Massachusetts Bonds.
J.M. Forbes: Refers to the market for the V.S. 5/20s bonds.
T.C. Baring to T. Baring, M.P.: Describes his visit to Virginia, giving a full account of conditions there.
J.N. Mason to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. interest due on the Virginia Sterling Debt in London.
R.B. Forbes to Sturgis - Enclosing a letter for Baring Bros. & Co. re an advance for a shipping venture.
S.G. Ward to T. Baring, M.P.: Eulogy of Mr. Bates.
R.B. Forbes: Ships model of a sloop of 60 to 100 tons.
G. Kemble to T. Baring, M.P.: Comments on the financial situation - Informs him of the Mission of General Schofield to Europe in regard to the French intervention in Mexico.
Stanton Blake to Baring Bros. & Co.: Instructions as to realizing into cash all the Massachusetts Sterling Bonds held by them for account of Blake Bros. & Co.
C. Whitehead to Baring Bros. & Co.: Thanking them for a letter of introduction to Dudley Mann &c. Mexican affairs.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring: State of the Money Market.
W.H. Aspinwall to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. sale of securities.

Archibald Gracie to T. Baring, M.P.: Introducing Sr. D. Madan Y Madan, a planter of Cuba who has a scheme for the emancipation of the slaves in that island upon the plan of compensation to the owners.
T.C. Baring to T. Baring, M.P.: Business affairs.
J.C. Burnham & Co.: Sugar market. Refers to "blockade runners".
Stanton Blake: Massachusetts loan.
J.M. Forbes: Sales of the Five-twenties bonds.
John Appleton to Joshua Bates - Arrangements re. draft for his salary as Minister at St. Petersburg.
W.H. Swift to Baring Bros. & Co. &c. Illinois and Michigan Canal affairs.

W. Hope, General Manager International & Financial Society Ltd. London, to The Trustees and Directors of the London and New York Steam Ship Co. Ltd.: Recapitulating the terms agreed upon between the promoters and this Society.
Edward C. Delavan to J. Bates - Re state of his account with Baring Bros. & Co.
D. Funston to Baring Bros. & Co.: Submitting a statement of the financial condition and resources of Virginia.
J.M. Forbes to Baring Bros. & Co.: Affairs as between the Northern Cross Railroad and the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad.
G.C. Ward to T. Baring, M.P.: Introducing Mr. Florence Huertas and giving an account of his business prospects.
Stanton Blake to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re Messrs. Hope & Co. Amsterdam, and the Massachusetts Loan-Enquiry re. regulation by which the British Government claims 1/8% stamp on foreign loans.
E. Butilh to J. Bates - Re. cancelling credits for account of his father's house in Trieste - and asking that they be renewed.
N. Silsbee to T. Baring: Acknowledging the receipt of a copy of his "Murillo" and comparing it with one he owns.
G.C. Ward to T. Baring: Apologizing for having, in the course of conversation touched upon matters beyond his province &c.
W.H. D.C. Wright to Baring Bros. & Co.: Regarding trouble between their Rio House and the Barings.
T.C. Baring: Business matter, Social life in New York.
W.H. Swift to S.G. Ward: Michigan Canal Trustees.
John A. Stevens, Bank of Commerce: The 5/20s U.S. Bonds.
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring, M.P.: The Chilian Loan - comments on the "Meteor" and his trial &c.
John A. Stevens to Baring Bros. & Co. New York Banks have entered into an agreement, securing united and carefully considered action and the power of a common fund of coin.

Weston & Gray to Baring Bros. & Co.: Concerning the position and financial standing of their firm and requesting an Exchange account of Â£10,000. N.B. Possibly successors to Messrs. Goodhue & Co. (?).
John Mollett to J. Bates - Submitting a memo re. a loan of Â£60,000 which the Russian American Company (St. Petersburg) wish to make.
John A. Stevens to Baring Bros. & Co.: Relative to his account.
George L. Schuyler to Baring Bros. & Co.: Asking explanation re credit established with them &c.
Lee Higginson & Co.: Will renew business intercourse.
Tirhoot Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Letter of guarantee for their letter of Credit for Â£40000 in favour of Gisborne & Co. Calcutta, for purposes of the Indigo Crop of 1862-3.
W.H. Swift to Baring Bros. & Co. &c.: Illinois and Michigan Canal.
Russell & Sturgis to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. their exchange credit - and their business generally.
W.H. Swift to S.G. Ward - Illinois and Michigan Canal.
Charles E. Kortright: Affairs of his brother; war news.
Blake Bros. & Co.: Massachusetts Sterling Bonds.
J. Heard to Russell Sturgis - Relative to the best method of placing funds in China for the use of the Russian Squadron.

J.M. Forbes to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. sale of the balance of the Jackson Lansing & Saginaw Railroad Co. Bonds - A memorandum made up by us from their reports and statements to serve until their prospectus is ready.
George Basil Dixwell to J. Bates: The interference of foreign powers in the Civil War, not probable - The insurrection in China and its possible effect.
Craig & Nichol: Refers to Bills of Lading and Exchange.
J.A. Cunningham to J.Bates: Asking for credit on Baring Bros. & Co. for Â£5000 to be used in Mauritius - with full explanations of why he needed it.
John A. Stevens; Bank of Commerce: Fluctuations in the price of 5/20s U.S. Bonds.
J.M. Forbes to Baring Bros. & Co.: Enclosing Prospectus - First Mortgage Bonds of the Jackson, Lansing and Saginaw Railroad Co., dated 20/2/1867.
J. Bancroft Davis to T. Baring - Giving his opinion on the question of stopping the ironclads.

T. Barings, M.P. to Lord Robert Cecil: His defense in the matter of the charges made against their House by him of violating the Queen's Proclamation of neutrality by shipping munitions of war to the Federal States. (Press Copy and drafts).
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring, M.P.: Chilian Bonds - scores Seward - discusses financial matters.
George Stanton to Baring Bros. & Co.: Requesting a credit for which he offers an absolute lien on ships owned wholly by himself.
J.M. Forbes: Personal. Mr. Aspinwall will be in London.
J.M. Forbes to Baring Bros. & Co.: Financial matters.
H. Devereux to J. Bates - Introducing his grandson, Charles U. Devereux and stating reasons for his going to England.
Charles H. Russell, President, National Bank of Commerce, New York, to Baring Bros. & Co.: Notifies them that he has assumed the Presidency on the retirement of John A. Stevens.
Padelford, Fay & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co. Re. shipments of iron - Financial troubles growing out of political agitations, (Press Copy)
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring, M.P.: Re. affairs of Messrs. Gavan, Lubbeck & Co. Quotes Mr. Forbes as making enquiries about a loan to a company of gentlemen.
Unsigned memo: George Peabody gave Â£150,000 for the London poor.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring - Record of Military operations since the 1st, instant. (Civil War)
John A. Stevens to Baring Bros. & Co.: Resignation of Mr. Secretary Chase and the appointment of Mr. Fessenden as his successor.
R.M. Blatchford: Request for credit of Â£200 in favour of John Munroe & Co.

W.H. Swift to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. Bonds of Northern Cross Railroad Co., Illinois, held by the Duke of Brunswick against the Chicago, Burlington & Quincy Railroad, the alleged guarantee of $1000000 unpaid Northern Cross Co. Bonds.
T.C. Baring to T. Baring - Enclosing copy of the articles of partnership of the firm Ward, Campbell and Co.
Eugene Rousseau, Cashier Citizens' Bank of Louisiana to Baring Bros. & Co. Re. investments at home rather than abroad at present rates of exchange.
By the Queen - Proclamation of neutrality in the case of the United States Civil War.
E.B. Graves to J. Bates - Re a credit guaranteed by them for Wm. K. Zim.
Charles Magniac, London to Sturgis: Has no copies of letters required of him.
G. Kemble to T. Baring, M.P.: Comments upon the war and its probable consequences.
J.M. Forbes to T. Baring, M.P.: His opinion re chances of friendship with Great Britain - The Alabama question and its consequences &c.
J.M. Forbes to Joshua Bates - Statement re affairs of Michigan Central Railroad.
Stanton Blake: Massachusetts Sterling Bonds.
Case of Benjamin Frye and Sally Frye, Salem: Re. Stock in Bank of England.
E.H. Green to Mr. Sturgis - Relative to a credit - Gives details of his business.
R.W. Weston to T. Baring: Re: political and monetary affairs.
Gisborne & Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: The effect of the possibility of war on commerce &c.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring: The progress of the war - political issues - the money market.
Stanton Blake to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re the possible issue of Massachusetts State Loan for the benefit of the Boston, Hartford and Erie Railroad Co.
C.G. Baylor to Baring Bros. & Co.: Relative to his forming a Company to be called the European and Mississippi Valley Navigation and Trading Company.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring, M.P.: Commenting upon the Cotton question and enclosing a letter from J.M. Forbes on the same subject.
James T. White (Robertson & Co.) to R. Sturgis: Re. question of Exchange in their dealings with Baring Bros. & Co.:
G. Forbes, Bank of England to T. Baring, M.P.: Informs him that there is a sinking fund for each of Guaranteed Colonial Loans.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring - requesting him to interview the Admiralty in respect to having a naval force on both sides of the Isthmus of Panama as a protection to British Commerce.
Thos. G. Cary to Sturgis - Re advances on Quicksilver shipped from San Francisco to China - enclosing copy of a previous letter.
W.H. Aspinwall to Baring Bros. & Co.: Relative to the establishment of a National Bank - How the subscriptions may be filled up &c - Enclosing letter from J.M. Forbes & Co. with details of the plan.
Augustine Heard, Jr. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Regarding Russian credits.
J.M. Forbes: Refers to the sale of the five-twenties bonds and the repercussions on the price of gold. Newspaper extract: Proposed large National Bank in New York.
John A. Stevens to Baring Bros. & Co.: Mr. Secretary Fessenden's information with regard to the four million dollars of bonds in their hands.
Horace Gray Jr. to Joshua Bates - Re. sales of cotton, breadstuffs &c.
John A. Stevens to Baring Bros. & Co.: Comments on Virginia and Maryland with respect to dis-union.
W.B. Franklin to W.H. Swift - The excited state of the country - efforts to find out the true state of affairs. (Press Copy)
J.M. Forbes: Alabama question. Relation with Great Britain.
G.C. Ward (W.C. & Co.) to T. Baring, M.P.: Relative to their over-drawn account.
Charles E. Kortright to T. Baring, M.P.: Relative to his brother's financial affairs - Comments on the progress of the war - and the estate of the money market.

John A. Stevens to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. Mr. Chase's expectation that the markets of Holland and Germany may be advantageously availed of by him for the disposal of United States securities and through the influence of the Bank of Commerce may include their firm.
Lord John Russell: Lord Palmerston would not mediate in the American affairs unless asked by both parties.

Col. George L. Schuyler to Baring Bros. & Co.: Enclosing papers signed by the Secretary of the Treasury, the Secretary of War &c, and enquiring whether on the strength of those, his drafts will be accepted.
W.H. Aspinwall to T. Baring - Enclosing memo re. establishing a Bank - Main office to be in New York - other agencies in Chicago, St. Louis, Cincinnati, New Orleans and San Francisco.
Hiram Roberts to Baring Bros. & Co.: Business matters.
John A. Stevens to J. Bates, Re news that New York State in importing arms - The conspiracy against the Government of the Country.
Thos. J. Fales, Secretary Colt's Patent F.A.M. Co. to Baring Bros. & Co.: Enquires re. American Securities to be used as Collaterals in order to have them meet his drafts.
George L. Schuyler to Baring Bros. & Co.: Re. his arrangements with Messrs. Hottinguer & Co. about his drafts.
T.C. Baring: Rumours of war in Europe.
